review.title: Constrained Bayesian Networks: Theory, Optimization, and Applications
review.abstract: We develop the theory and practice of an approach to modelling and probabilistic inference in causal networks that is suitable when application-specific or analysis-specific constraints should inform such inference or when little or no data for the learning of causal network structure or probability values at nodes are available. Constrained Bayesian Networks generalize a Bayesian Network such that probabilities can be symbolic, arithmetic expressions and where the meaning of the network is constrained by finitely many formulas from the theory of the reals. A formal semantics for constrained Bayesian Networks over first-order logic of the reals is given, which enables non-linear and non-convex optimisation algorithms that rely on decision procedures for this logic, and supports the composition of several constrained Bayesian Networks. A non-trivial case study in arms control, where few or no data are available to assess the effectiveness of an arms inspection process, evaluates our approach. An open-access prototype implementation of these foundations and their algorithms uses the SMT solver Z3 as decision procedure, leverages an open-source package for Bayesian inference to symbolic computation, and is evaluated experimentally.

sections.text: Article VI of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT) [1] states that each Party "undertakes to continue negotiations in good faith on effective measures to end the nuclear arms race at an early stage and on nuclear disarmament and on a Treaty on General and Full Disarmament under strict and effective international supervision." An important aspect of the fulfilment of such treaty obligations can be the creation and conduct of trustworthy inspection processes, for example to verify that an item that can be held accountable has not become inoperable. Designing such processes is a challenge as it must ensure sufficient mutual trust between the reviewed and verifying parties in the presence of potentially conflicting interests. Without such trust, the Parties could not agree to carry out such inspections. The potential benefits of mathematical models for designing and evaluating such inspection processes are obvious.

sections.text: This implementation uses Python to collect a data model for Bayesian networks and constraints, to formulate interesting margins, and to interface with the SMT solver Z3 [23], which we use as the decision-making process for Logic Q, which also provides witness information for all variables. sections.heading: 6 Discussion
sections.text: Our approach advocates the use of limited Bayesian networks as a means of gaining trust in Bayesian network modeling and inferring in the face of little or no data. Therefore, a modeler could start with a BN, turn it into several limited BNs and analyze them, and perhaps modify the BN based on such findings. Witness information computed in analyses could in principle be returned to a BN modeling tool so that users can see a concrete BN that explains, for example, how to achieve a marginal value in a limited BN. The ability to present witness information as a concrete BN is also a means of testing whether the calculation of the symbolic meaning of marginals is free of errors. We have actually performed such tests to gain confidence in the correctness of our tool and the packages on which it depends.
